and is one of the inhabited islands of Alif Alif Atoll with an almost completely Sunni Muslim population of about 900.

value: File:Under water to be seeing by snorkeling at Ukulhas Island.jpg
Snorkelling just off the coast at Ukulhas Island

Although this flat, coral sand cay is only 1025m long and just 225m at its widest point, it's one of the best diving spots on the planet. The icing on the cake is the complete honesty and friendliness of the local people!

After the island capital of Malé, this island was the first to be electrified and is still one of the very few outside the capital with mains electricity at 220-240V, 50Hz, 24/7. Sockets are usually 3-pin UK type, but most accommodation establishments will have adapters for other types.

No land anywhere on Ukulhas is more than the height of a tall man above the high water mark and all of the Maldives are probably doomed to be inundated by rising seas during the next century.

The hottest month is typically April and the coolest December. February is the driest, with December through April usually the driest months.

is spoken here, as in all parts of the Maldivian archipelago. Because there is a good school here teaching to British A-level standard, and because of the burgeoning tourism industry, good English is widely spoken.
A ferry leaves Male’s Villigili Jetty on Sunday, Tuesday and Thursday at 09:00 and takes about 4.5h to reach Ukulhas island and is free for locals. A faster and more costly alternative is the

seaplane for about USD310 return.

The distance between
and Ukulhas island is just over 70km.
